Title: Randomised Controlled Trial Comparing Nonoperative Treatment and Hemiarthroplasty for Four-Part Proximal Humerus Fractures in the Elderly

Background: Four-part fractures of the proximal humerus are challenging to treat in the elderly. This study compares nonoperative treatment and hemiarthroplasty in terms of function, strength, and pain.

Methods: In this randomised controlled trial, 50 patients aged 65 years and older with four-part proximal humerus fractures were randomly allocated to nonoperative treatment or hemiarthroplasty. The primary outcome was the Constant-Murley score at 12 months. Secondary outcomes included the Simple Shoulder Test, abduction strength measured by a myometer, and VAS scores for pain and disability. Randomisation was performed using a computer-generated sequence, and allocation was concealed. Outcome assessors were blinded to group allocation.

Results: At 12 months, there were no significant differences between groups in Constant-Murley and Simple Shoulder Test scores. Nonoperative treatment resulted in better abduction strength at 3 and 12 months, but patients experienced more pain at 3 months, which was not evident at 12 months. No adverse events were reported in either group.

Interpretation: Both nonoperative treatment and hemiarthroplasty offer similar outcomes for elderly patients with four-part proximal humerus fractures. Nonoperative treatment may provide better strength, but initial pain is higher.
